perturbation.changed_text:
3.   COMPENSATION OF THE PROFESSIONAL.  In consideration of the rights          granted to the Company and the services to be provided by the           Professional, the Professional shall receive the following           compensation:

    4.   PAYMENTS. All payments to be made to the Professional pursuant to the          terms of this Agreement shall be made within 30 days of invoice and           delivered to ________________________________________________________           _____________________________________________________________________



         _____________________________________________________________________

         or at such other address as shall be designated in writing by          Professional. Payments may be made within 60 days if, at the company's discretion, cash flow is limited.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces conflicting payment terms. The first clause mandates all payments be made, implying adherence to standard payment schedules. The added clause allows for payments within 60 days at the company's discretion due to cash flow limitations, contradicting the initial payment obligation. This creates ambiguity regarding the payment deadline and provides the company with a discretionary extension, causing uncertainty in enforcement.

perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a conflict regarding termination rights. The original clause states conditions under which *either* party can terminate the agreement, specifically outlining a 30-day cure period for defaults. The added clause grants the Professional the unilateral right to terminate the agreement *at any time, for any reason, with no penalty*. This directly contradicts the original termination conditions, creating uncertainty regarding which terms govern termination. Is a 30-day notice required, or can the Professional terminate immediately? The contract is now ambiguous.

9.   SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS. This Agreement may not be assigned by the           Professional under any circumstances. The Company shall not be           entitled to assign this Agreement to any other party without the           Professional's express prior written consent, except any assignment           by the Company as a result of a stock exchange, merger, consolidation,          or sale of substantially all of the assets of the Company, in which           case not such consent shall be required.

    10.  SEVERABILITY. Should any one or more of the provisions of this           Agreement be determined to be illegal or unenforceable, all other          provisions of this Agreement shall be given effect separately from the          provision or provisions determined to be illegal or unenforceable.

9.   SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS. This Agreement may not be assigned by the           Professional under any circumstances. The Company shall not be           entitled to assign this Agreement to any other party without the           Professional's express prior written consent, except any assignment           by the Company as a result of a stock exchange, merger, consolidation,          or sale of substantially all of the assets of the Company, in which           case not such consent shall be required.     10.  SEVERABILITY. Should any one or more of the provisions of this           Agreement be determined to be illegal or unenforceable, all other          provisions of this Agreement shall be given effect separately from the          provision or provisions determined to be illegal or unenforceable.
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation introduces a conflict regarding assignment rights. Section 9 clearly states the Professional cannot assign the agreement 'under any circumstances'. However, the modified text adds a clause allowing the Professional to assign receivables to a factoring company. While not a full assignment of the contract, assigning receivables effectively transfers a portion of the rights and benefits of the agreement to a third party, directly contradicting the 'under any circumstances' clause. This creates uncertainty about the scope of the assignment restriction and whether assigning receivables is permitted.
